message_1: A certain amount of radioactive material has a half-life of 20 years. If the initial amount of the material is 1000 grams, how much will be left after 60 years?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the formula for radioactive decay:

Final amount = Initial amount * (1/2)^(time elapsed / half-life)

In this case, the initial amount is 1000 grams, the time elapsed is 60 years, and the half-life is 20 years. Plugging these values into the formula, we get:

Final amount = 1000 * (1/2)^(60 / 20)

Final amount = 1000 * (1/2)^3

Final amount = 1000 * (1/8)

Final amount = 125 grams

So, after 60 years, there will be 125 grams of the radioactive material left.
